: SHORTAGE OF MEDICINES IN GOVERNMENT HOSPITALS:
(i) the cases of unavailability of certain drugs and inadequacy of stocks are reported in some public hospitals; and
(ii) patients are severely inconvenienced as a result?
(i) the agencies responsible for procurement and distribution of medicines to public hospitals, separately;
(ii) the reasons for the frequent medicine shortages in public hospitals; and
(iii) the measures that have been taken to prevent the recurrence of such incidents?
() ( ) ( ( ) - ) (The Hon. (Dr.) Ramesh Pathirana - Minister of Industries and Minister of Health) , .
SRI LANKA TRANSPORT BOARD: DAILY INCOME AND FUEL
asked the Minister of Transport and Highways:
(i) the daily income earned by the Sri Lanka Transport Board;
(ii) the number of kilometres that the fleet of buses of the Sri Lanka Transport Board run on a daily basis;
(iii) the daily fuel requirement for the aforesaid schedule; and
(b) If not, why? () ( ) ( () - ) (The Hon. (Dr.) Bandula Gunawardana - Minister of Transport and Highways and Minister of Mass Media) , .
() , ? asked the Minister of Transport and Highways:
(i) the bridge from Velanaithurai to Pungudutivu, Madaththuveli, which is located in the Velanai Divisional Secretarys Division in the Jaffna District, is one of the longest bridges in Sri Lanka;
(ii) it has become very dangerous to cross the aforesaid bridge; and
(iii) many accidents occur on this bridge?
(i) the length of the aforesaid bridge;
(ii) the factors that cause the aforesaid accidents;
(iii) the year in which the aforesaid bridge was last renovated;
(iv) the amount of money that was spent on the aforesaid renovation work;
(v) the funding source for such renovation; and
(vi) the time frame within which the aforesaid bridge will be completely renovated?

asked the Prime Minister and Minister of Public Administration, Home Affairs, Provincial Councils and Local Government:
(i) the number of persons who have been recruited by the Department of Multi-Purpose Development Task Force under the programme of providing 100,000 employment opportunities;
(ii) the respective institutions and posts to which the said employees are attached;
(iii) the number of employed persons who have been confirmed in the service to date;
(iv) the existing programme for the confirmation of the job holders who have not yet been confirmed in the service; and
(v) whether a promotion strategy and welfare programme have been prepared for the above employees?
(b) If not, why? ( ) ( - , , ) (The Hon. Dinesh Gunawardena - Prime Minister and Minister of Public Administration, Home Affairs, Provincial Councils and Local Government) , .

(ii) if so, what the aforesaid guidelines are?

: EIGHTEEN RETIRED EMPLOYEES OF SRI LANKA BROADCASTING CORPORATION: GRANT OF PENSION
asked the Minister of Mass Media: (a) Is he aware that -

(i) pensions are yet to be paid to 18 employees who had retired 25 years ago after serving in the Sri Lanka Broadcasting Corporation (SLBC) as recommended by the Human Rights Commission of Sri Lanka and the Public Petitions Committee of the Parliament;
(ii) all Secretaries to the Ministries have been informed to implement the recommendations made by the Human Rights Commission through Public Administration Circular 17/2005;
(iii) the then Chairman of the SLBC had informed the then Minister and the Secretary that the aforesaid 18 employees are entitled to receive pensions; and
(iv) even the then Additional Director to the Ministry of Mass Media had recommended to the Director General of Pensions that pensions are needed to be paid to the aforesaid employees as well?
(b) If so, will he inform this House of the date the pensions will be paid to the aforesaid 18 employees?
( ) ( - ) (The Hon. Shantha Bandara - State Minister of Mass Media) , .

asked the Minister of Power and Energy:

(ii) if so, what underlying factors influenced the reaching of that decision;
(iii) the objectives of installing that oil pipeline; and
(iv) the effect the installing of the oil pipeline will have on the energy sector of Sri Lanka?

asked the Prime Minister and Minister of Public Administration, Home Affairs, Provincial Councils and Local Government:
(i) the number of organizations proscribed after the Easter attack in Sri Lanka;
(iii) the reasons that led to the proscription of those organisations;
(iv) out of those organisations, the organisations of which the proscription has been lifted at present;
(v) the reasons that led to the lifting of such proscription; and

(vi) the measures that have already been taken and the measures that will be taken in future in order to enforce the law against the persons who are directly and indirectly responsible for the Easter attack?

: FISH STOCKS AVAILABLE DURING GLUTS: STORAGE
) ( - .. ) (The Hon. Buddhika Pathirana on behalf of the Hon. U.K. Sumith Udukumbura) - (1):
(i) whether there is a process to purchase and stock fish during gluts in Sri Lanka;
(ii) if so, whether there are storage facilities available for buffer stocks;
(iii) whether there is a procedure to ensure the availability of fish at reasonable prices during lean periods; and
(iv) whether there is a safety net which protects both the fisherman and the consumer?
(b) If not, why? () ( () ) (The Hon. (Dr.) Susil Premajayantha, Attorney-at-Law) , * .

asked the Minister of Agriculture and Plantation Industries:
(i) the coconut prices prevailed in Sri Lanka in each of the years from 2018 to 2022, separately;
(ii) whether there has been an escalation in price of coconut as against the production cost; and
(iii) what measures have been adopted by the Government to keep the price of coconut at a high level?
(b) Will he also inform the House -
(i) how many coconuts were imported to Sri Lanka in each of the years from 2018 to 2022 and what expenditure was borne for that in each year, separately;
(ii) which countries the coconuts were imported from and who the importers were, separately; and
(iii) the reasons for importing coconut to Sri Lanka?
(c) If not, why? () ( () ) (The Hon. (Dr.) Susil Premajayantha, Attorney-at-Law) , * .

, . , , Plantation Management Monitoring Division quit notice .

Hon. Minister, the Plantation Management Monitoring Division was created to monitor the RPCs, not the workers. When the Agreement between the Sri Lankan Government and the 22 RPCs was signed - the golden shareholder is the Secretary to the Treasury - they created a division called the Plantation Management Monitoring Division under the Ministry of Plantation Industries to monitor the management of those estates. But, Hon. Minister, I am sorry to say that the Plantation Management Monitoring Division is not monitoring the companies, but the workers. They are sending quit notices and are pulling the workers out onto the road after
working in the estates for four to five generations, for the last 200 years. I think, Hon. Minister, you must know this. Please, I want you to get involved in this matter.

About 16,000 hectares of land have been abandoned by the RPCs. At that time, the Government leased out the estates of three institutions - the JEDB, the SPC and the "Usawasama ", which is now called the Elkaduwa Plantations Limited - to the 22 RPCs for easy management. But, Hon. Minister, do you know what ultimately happened? There are only five owners for those 22 companies; they go under different names, but there are only five owners. They are running a mafia in the plantation sector, violating the labour law, violating the Collective Agreement. They are fighting with the Minister of Labour; they are going to court against the Government Gazette with regard to the workers' wages. What is this, Hon. Minister? They have been paying the workers only Rs. 1,000 per day for the last three years. Now, the cost of living has gone up, everybody knows that. The employees of all the sectors are getting wage increases. The Hon. President summoned those 22 companies and informed them to do the needful to pay a daily wage of Rs. 1,700 or more. Still, they are delaying that. State properties have been abandoned; they have closed down the factories, which are now called silent factories. Sir, 1.2 million workers were there when the Government handed over those estates to the RPCs in 1992. Now, only 143,000 workers are there, but the extent of land is the same. As a result, all the estates have become jungles and there are wild animals also. Out of those 143,000 workers, 80 per cent are women. The male workers stood against the management and most of them have now left the estates. They are coming out with a lot of stories, but all are lies, Hon. Minister. Sir, we like this country and want to serve our nation. So, please take steps, Hon. Minister, regarding this matter, I am humbly requesting you.

Also, Sir, when the JEDB, the SLSPC and Elkaduwa Plantations Limited lease out those estates to private companies, they have to settle the EPF and ETF contributions of the workers. They still have an amount of Rs. 500 million to settle as EPF and ETF.
( ) (The Hon. Presiding Member) Hon. Member, please wind up. ( ) (The Hon. Vadivel Suresh) Please give me two more minutes, Sir.

Hon. Minister, without the approval of the PMMD, they cannot cut trees. But, they have cut trees; non-stop, they have been cutting trees. As a result, in the up-country, we are now facing earthslips. In those days, we did not have this number of earthslips. Now, it is happening because they have cut trees. Hon. Minister, please send a monitoring team and check on that. So, that is what is happening. Then, those "silent factories" belong to the Government and the RPCs are selling the iron in those factories; they have removed the machines and sold everything.

It being 5.30 p.m.., THE HON. PRESIDING MEMBER adjourned Parliament without Question put.
Parliament adjourned accordingly at 5.30 p.m. until 9.30 a.m. on Friday, 12th January, 2024.
Corrections which Members suggest for the Final Print of their speeches should be clearly marked in their copy and
sent to the Editor of HANSARD within two weeks of receipt of the uncorrected copy.
